The intention of this part is to make you able to understand possible issues with your numerical model. This understanding will be useful to evaluate and overcome issues with the numerical routines.It is also intended to make you aware about typical parameters of the numerical scheme, e.g., the head closure criterion.Finally, the knowledge can help you to increase the efficiency of your numerical model, for example by choosing suitable parameters for the numerical solver or by optimizing the discretization. An efficient computation can be very beneficial for subsequent model use like uncertainty analysis and automatic calibration, where the numerical model is executed several times.
No notes
No notes
No notes

The subsurface usually exhibits a layered structure, e.g. a sequence of well and poorly conductive layers.  The horizontal extension of layers is significantly larger than the vertical extension. Therefore, vertical averaging of flow is frequently justified.This concept was used for the development of many software packages and most groundwater models therefore consist of a set of model layers. “Real“ 3D models are rare.A 2D groundwater model consists of a single model layer.more than one model layer: quasi-3D model (or “2D+“).Model layers can coincide with hydrogeological layers.If a better vertical resolution is intended, a hydrogeological layer is represented by several model layers. Vertical water transfer between model layers can be considered.It is not necessary to provide separate layers for aquitards. Rather, it is frequently sufficient to define appropriate vertical conductivities between adjacent model layers (“leaky aquifer“).
Short explanation about the 2D finite difference grid. This is very similar to the 1D setup discussed in earlier classes.

Groundwater flow in FD models occurs in parallel to one of the coordinate axes (double arrows in the figure).FD equations are based on the conservation of volume and Darcy‘s Law. They contain quantities from five cells (except at domain boundaries or for cells with given head values).In order to evaluate Darcy‘s Law it is necessary to compute conductivities or transmissivities for cell edges.
No notes

Procedure and model input dataIn order to determine hydraulic head values at time level k only head values from the preceding time level k-1 are used (one-step method).model input data required:	–	aquifer parameters (storage coefficient, transmissivity) for each cell	–	initial values of hydraulic head hij0 for each cell	–	information about sources / sinks (water injection / extraction) or 	boundary 	conditions like groundwater recharge (usually cell-specific)	–	discretisation parameters (cell widths, number of cells, time step length, 	number of time steps)

The aim is to go through all the steps required to build the equation systems, just as the computer would.We consider an idealized 2D catchment witha river,recharge,a pumping well.The question for the model is: Can river water infiltrate the aquifer and reach the pumping well?

This is the idealized conceptual model with the boundary conditions.For simplicity, the river is considered as 1st type boundary with a defined head (of course, the simplification is the only reason to choose 1st type for the river).

The conceptual model is transferred in a simple numerical model.The numerical model is built from 6 cells, each cell with an index (the number of the cell)The discretization in space is differing for the cells (see the figure).
The hydrogeological properties are ‘heterogeneous’ with two different transmissivities T.
Step 1Computee the water balance for all cells.

Step 2a:Setup the equations for discharge.This is simply Darcy's law.Consider for Transmissivity the weighted harmonic mean of the values of the two cells.The slide shows the equation for Q_12 = Flow between cells 1 and 2.

Step 2b:account for the specific parameter values, and combine all terms.The final equation contains only little terms.In the example, the equations contains the unknow head h_2.(This approach highlights the need to be consistent with time and space units throughout the model!)

Step 2cFor the complete mass balance of cell 2, we also need to calculate Q_52 and Q_32.In addition, we have to compute the flow through the boundary conditionsQ_r for the recharge andQ_p for the pumping wellFinally, we can combine all equations to calculate the water balance of cell 2. This equation contains the three unknown heads (of cells 2, 3, and 5).
Step 2d:Do the same procedure (writing down the water balance) for all other cells (of course not for cells 1 and 4, which are the defined head boundary).

Step 3: Setting up the equation systemThis are all equations for the model (4 inner cells)Each equation (one equation for each cell) contains the unknow headsPlease note: each equation contains all unknowns! Those who are not part of the water balance are simply multiplied by 0.The final set of equations contains:a matrix of coefficients (the red part), which contains the information from the parameters, cells sized and so on (see previous slides)the unknown heads (the blue part)and the source terms (the green part), which contain the information from boundaries and so on (see previous slides, those terms of the water balance that do not contain an unknow head)The system of equations can be written as matrixes in the form of A x = b (see figure)A is usually named LHS (= left hand side)b is usually named RHS (= right hand side)
Step 3: Setting up the equation systemHere written as matrixes
Step 4: Solve the equation systemHere, an equation for each unknown head is derived.

Step 4: Solve the equation systemSolution by iteration – using the starting values / values from the previous iteration for the unknown heads (remember the XLS sheet for the 1D numerical solution…)The index j represent the iteration stepThe solution converge if the maximum difference in head between two iterations is smaller than the user-defined threshold
The final heads can be compared to other numerical solutions (e. g., from MODFLOW)

Computation of the cell water budetWater flows according to the hydraulic gradient.With the know heads, also the hydraulic gradients are know.Accordingly, we can compute the discharge.We can also compute the complete balance.
Global water budgetComputed by the respective terms of the water balance.
Global water budgetAnalysis and discussion
Transfer of knowledge:The model can be setup in MODELMUSE to compare resultsHeadsBudget

Example for motivationThe figure origin from the MODFLOW-NWT documentation, and it illustrates a very challenging situation for groundwater models.The spatial extent is several kilometers (catchment scale).The model consider a defined head at the lowest point of the aquifer bottom, which serve as outlet.Imagine: What would happen if the hydraulic conductivity is large? Of course, water (originating from groundwater recharge) would easily move to the outlet.But also with a moderate hydraulic conductivity, the solution is strongly depending on the initial heads (with higher elevated parts starting ‘dry’).

Another example for motivation:The cross section shows a horizontal flow barrier (slurry wall ranging from the surface up to a depth of 120 m).The horizontal flow barrier is intended to ‘block’ groundwater flow.The colors in the figure represent hydraulic heads, showinghigh heads on the left sidelower heads on the right sideThe streamlines (in yellow in the figure) also show that no flow occurs from the left side to the right side if the upper part of the right side is ‘dry’.The numbers in the example are the results from an analytical solution. They show:Hydraulic heads are correctly computed by MODFLOW-2005Flow Q through the barrier is underestimated.

Another example for motivation (cont.):Here, the same situation is computed with MODFLOW-NWTThe flowlines indicate that also the ‘dry’ part of the model is ‘active’ allowing water to enter these ‘dry’ cells.MODFLOW-NWT correctly compute the discharge through the horizontal flow barrier.

(Some) solvers in MODFLOW:Various approaches are provided.Generalized approach: MODFLOW is a tool for many situations …What solver for which situation?Knowledge (Knowing that there is more than one solver),Experience,Trial and error …

Example of an approach to deal with ‘dry’ cells:(1) Rewetting option in MODFLOWCan result in instabilities(2) Modifying the equation for transmissivity:Even if the hydraulic head is below the cell bottom, the transmissivity is not ‘zero’But: the approach can result in numerical issues (instability?)
(3) Alternative formulation – MODFLOW-NWTreleased in 2011Newton solver and (NWT)Different formulation of the flow package (UPW)
Upstream Weighting Flow (UPW):Transmissivity is based on the saturation of the upstream cellallows flow in ‘dry’ cells
Newton solver (NWT)excellent explanation in Mehl (2006)https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1745-6584.2006.00207.x

Typical ‘Cobweb’ patternThis plot demonstrates the behaviour of an so-called Picard-Iteration.Most iterative MODFLOW solvers account for Picard-Iterations.They grey function f(h) represents the modelThe shown function is an exampleThe function is unknow for a real modelThe general functioning can be described as ‘starting heads h of the iteration result in a model behaviour f(h) (like fows, discharges..)The behaviour is explained for an example on the following slide.

Behaviour of the cobweb pattern for Picard-iterationsThe iteration starts with starting heads (A)The starting heads generate a ‘model response’ (B)The model response (B) is reflected on the inflection point (C) …… and results in new heads (D)The new heads (D) generate a new model response ….… model response generates new heads …… new heads generate model response …This continues until the difference between two heads is smaller than the closure criteria (or the max number of iterations is reached).Perfect closure is achieved if the heads result in a model reaction that confirms the heads (i.e., if the model f(h) hits the 45 degree dotted line)

Behaviour of the cobweb pattern for Picard-iterations (example 2)In this example the model behaves different.The steps (nonlinearity) can be caused by nonlinear boundary conditions, e.g., an outflow that is activated if heads reach a specific value (see Mehl 2006 for more explanation)Use the scheme by yourself:(1) start with an initial head of 6 (2) start with an initial head of 3.5

Behaviour of the cobweb pattern for Picard-iterations (example 3)In this example the model behaves (again) kdifferent.The steps (nonlinearity) can be caused by nonlinear boundary conditions, e.g., an outflow that is activated if heads reach a specific value (see Mehl 2006 for more explanation)Use the scheme by yourself:(1) start with an initial head of 6 (2) start with an initial head of 0.5

Newton-Iteration (Scheme)The basic idea is that the scheme generates the derivative of the modelbased on starting heads (1.75 in the example) the derivative becomes zero (represented by the horizontal line at f(h) = 0This head (in the example 1) is the new start for the next derivativeThis continues until the point is found where the model hits the horizontal f(h) = 0 linePlease note that in this example, the pattern converges only if the starting heads are > 0.2The plot marks the heads with convergence by the thick black bar on the top (non convergence with the thick black bar on the bottom)

Newton-Iteration (Scheme) – ExampleThis example illustrates that the solution (convergence) is (very) dependent from the initial values.If the scheme use suitable initial values, the convergence can be achieved in an effective manner (i.e., less iterations)

MODFLOW-NWT Documentation – Test exampleThe test example is 1D unconfined flowThe solution can be achieved with an analytical solution (shown in the top of the slide)This example is comparable / similar to our 1D-11 cell model and the analytical solutions discussed earlierin this example the two defined heads are h1 = 10 m and h2 = 50 m, the distance between the two boundaries is 5,000 m.The red line is the head computed by the analytical solutionThe blue/violet lines represent the deviation of heads for the MODFLOW-2005 and MODFLOW-NWT solutions

MODFLOW-NWT Documentation – Test example (cont.)The solution of MODFLOW-NWT is less precisedeviates more if the head gradient is step (left side of the plot)the reason is the upstream weighting (UPW) upstream weighting computes the transmissivity based on the (higher) heads in upstream directionaccordingly, in the example the transmissivity tends to be too large and heads are too smallThe figure illustrate this with a very coarse grid (cell 1 and 2 with the saturated thickness b that is accounted by MODFLOW-2005 and MODFLOW-NWT)
MODFLOW-NWT Documentation – Test exampleThe table shows the heads and flows.

Alternative approach to ‘classical’ Graphical User InterfacesScript-based approaches generate the required input files for MODFLOWScript-based approaches process the results of the MODFLOW computationAn example for a popular script-based approach is FloPy – A Python library for MODFLOW pre- and postprocessingThe workflow with script-based modeling can be very advantageous:extremely scaleable (run multiple variants of a model by calling the script with different parameters with insignificant user-effort)very comprehensive (compare a model script from different stages/times to see the differences)Extremly efficient (generate all plots and data for postprocessing with no additional effort)
